definition:
Let $E$ be a Euclidean vector space, $R\subset E$ a root system, and
$R^+\subset R$ a choice of positive roots. We define the [ *positive
Weyl chamber*]{} (relative to $R^+$) to be the closed set
$$\mathcal{C}=\{u\in E\mid (u,\alpha)\geq 0\text{ for all }\alpha\in
R^+\}.$$ A weight which lies inside the positive Weyl chamber is called
[*dominant*]{}.

The interior of $\mathcal{C}$ is a fundamental domain for the action of
the Weyl group on $E$. The image $w(\mathcal{C})$ of $\mathcal{C}$ under
the any element $w$ of the Weyl group is called a [*Weyl chamber*]{}.
The Weyl group $W$ acts simply transitively on the set of Weyl chambers.
